title: Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe endorses negative interest rates in paper
text:
Australian home borrowers could soon be paid money to take out a mortgage from the bank.

In August, Danish banks offered the world's first negative mortgage interest rate, paying borrowers a 0.5 per cent rate if they took out a loan.

Australia could now follow suit with Reserve Bank Governor Philip Lowe endorsing the idea of negative interest rates.

Scroll down for video

Australian home borrowers could soon be paid money to take out a mortgage from the bank. In August, Danish banks offered the world's first negative mortgage interest rate, which has offered to pay borrowers a 0.5 per cent rate if they took out a loan (pictured is a stock image)

He has co-authored a paper for the Bank for International Settlements, a Swiss-based group run by the world's central banks, suggesting the policy had worked where it had been tried.

'Central banks judged that negative policy rates contributed to the achievement of their policy goals and that their side effects have been contained,' he said.

Interest rates in Australia are now below one per cent for the first time ever, after the RBA last week cut the cash rate by a quarter of a percentage point to 0.75 per cent.

That means Australia is just three cuts away from having zero interest rates, a situation known as quantitative easing where the central bank buys government bonds to effectively boost the supply of money.

Should rates by cut further than that, in a bid to boost a slow economy, Australia would be in negative interest rate territory along with Denmark, Switzerland, Sweden and Japan.

While the idea may seem far-fetched, Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe (pictured) has endorsed the idea of negative interest rates. He has co-authored a paper for the Bank for International Settlements, a Swiss-based group run by the world's central banks, suggesting the policy had worked where it had been tried

Denmark's third largest bank, the Jyske Bank, is offering borrowers a negative 0.5 per cent rate a year for ten years.

A rival bank, Nordea, is offering the minus 0.5 per cent rate for 30 years.

Dr Lowe endorsed zero or negative interest rates, arguing they had helped the world economy recover from the Global Financial Crisis a decade ago.

'The report concludes that, on balance, unconventional monetary policy tools helped the central banks that used them address the circumstances presented by the crisis and the ensuing economic downturn,' he said as chairman of the Bank for International Settlements Committee on the Global Financial System.

Dr Lowe also said they had 'been fairly effective' in reducing money market rates, where banks borrow funds short-term to lend to customers.

In August, he told a parliamentary committee 'unlikely but it is possible' interest rates could hit zero in Australia.

'We are prepared to do unconventional things if the circumstances warranted it,' Dr Lowe said.

The biggest obstacle to borrowers getting paid interest to borrow would be the banks themselves, with none of Australia's major lenders this month matching the Reserve Bank of Australia's 0.25 percentage point interest rate cut.

authors: Stephen Johnson For Daily Mail Australia
